title_sort: lewis k. brown to walt whitman, 22 august 1863
title: Lewis K. Brown to Walt Whitman, 22 August 1863
text: Dear Friend Walt,Both of your letters came to hand, in due time & I insure you I was glad to hear from you and to hear that you wer[were] enjoying good health. Dear Walt, I beg to be excused for not writing sooner, but to tell the truth we have had a good many visitors and when there was not visitors I was away, but you need not think that I have forgotton[forgotten] you. Your memory burns as bright as ever in my heart & allways[always] will, thear[there] is now doubt but some of my corrospondants[correspondents] in Washington has begin to think hard of me for not writing oftener, but I will be thear[there] my self before long to make excuses'es[excuses] in person. I will be thear[there] on the last day of August, if I do not get my furlow[furlough] extended, whitch[which] I have the hopes of, for I would most as leave come back to see my old friends as stay at home. The Doctor that tens me hear wants me for to try and get my furlow[furlough] extended, for he thinks that my leg will get worse if I go back while the weather is so hot, but I do not know how it will be yet (wont you advise me which is best) The Doctor thinks that he can have my furlow[furlough] extended verry[very] easy. Dear Walter I am enjoying my self fine as well, I think, as any cripple can. I was up to Quaker or Friends Quartily[Quarterly] Meeting yesterday. (I expect you know what it is and may be have bin[been] at one) thear[there] was a great many thear[there] & I seen a great many of my relations & freinds[friends] thear[there] that I would not of seen if I had of stayed away. they had exelant[excellent] preaching, but you must know that they are are on the Piece principle, and you know that I aint[ain't]. I am for war as long as there is men & money until this sccussed Rebellion is put down for thear[there] has bin[been] to many good lives lost allready[already] for to ever make a compromise, do not you think so.Well Dear Walter, it is just in the highth[height] of the Peach & Appel[apple] season and we have some nice Peaches but we have not got any Apples now for our early ons are dun and we have not many late ones. We have some few Watermellons[watermelons] & cantilopes[cantaloupes] but not many I often think of the poor boys in the Hospital when I am eating themWalter I have no news to write so I will have to close this miserable scrach[scratch] for I am aware that it is verry[very] porely[poorly] wrote (but I never mind the writing if the heart is all wright) so you must not mind this so with mutch[much] love to you; and all enquiring friends I will bid you good by and God bless you from your friend and companion. Lewis K. Brown to Walt Whitman, 22 August 1863
